content: The "Airline Passenger Fairness Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. The findings of the Act are also outlined. The Congress finds that the number of airline passengers on US carriers is expected to grow to 1 billion by 2008. The number of certified large air carriers has decreased, with 6 major carriers forming 3 large networks. Many communities have lost scheduled air service, and smaller airlines now serve half of those remaining. Only 2/3 of communities in the US with scheduled air service in 1978 still have it today, with half of those served by smaller airlines feeding hub airports. A 1997 report showed 75 city pairs with fares increasing by 30% or more, leading to a decrease in total traffic. A 1998 study found that large US air carriers charge twice as much at hub airports without low fare competition compared to those with low fare competitors. The General Accounting Office found that large US air carriers charge significantly higher fares at hub airports without low fare competition compared to those with low fare competitors. Complaints about airline travel have increased by over 25% from the previous year, with a notable rise in complaints against large US air carriers. The 1997 National Civil Aviation Review Commission reported a worsening trend in flight delays, with a nearly 20% increase in daily aircraft delays of 15 minutes or longer in 1996 compared to 1995. The number of US air carriers increased from 6,394 in 1997 to 7,994 in 1998. The 1997 National Civil Aviation Review Commission reported a worsening trend in flight delays, with a nearly 20% increase in daily aircraft delays of 15 minutes or longer in 1996 compared to 1995. Forecasts show a 52% increase in passenger enplanements between 1996 and 2006, with annual growth in revenue passenger miles averaging 4.2%. A 1998 Department of Transportation study found that large US air carriers charge about 60% more for passengers traveling to or from small communities. The Federal Aviation Administration forecasts 4.2% annual growth in revenue passenger miles between 1996 and 2006. A 1998 Department of Transportation study found that large US air carriers charge about 60% more for passengers traveling to or from small communities. Congress has directed the Secretary of Transportation to prohibit unfair practices in the airline industry. SEC. 3. FAIR PRACTICES FOR AIRLINE PASSENGERS. Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code is amended to include specific practices for certificated air carriers, such as informing passengers about oversold flights, allowing the use of portions of a ticket, and delivering checked baggage within 24 hours. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code includes practices for certificated air carriers: allowing passengers to use portions of their ticket, delivering checked baggage within 24 hours, providing full access to all fares, and giving notice of flight delays to passengers with confirmed reservations. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code requires certificated air carriers to provide various consumer protections, including informing passengers of flight delays, accurately explaining reasons for delays, offering refunds for unused tickets within 48 hours of purchase, and disclosing information on frequent flyer programs. The amended Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code mandates certificated air carriers to provide consumer protections, such as offering refunds for unused tickets within 48 hours of purchase and disclosing information on frequent flyer programs, including seat availability and redemption success rates. The Secretary will report violations in the monthly Air Travel Consumer Report. The term 'confirmed reserved space' refers to a specific date and flight. The Secretary will report violations of consumer protection regulations by certificated air carriers in the monthly Air Travel Consumer Report. The term 'confirmed reserved space' refers to a specific date, flight, and class of service requested by a passenger.
